header_1: H5N1 in Wild birds in South Korea
content_1: . Quarantine officials found 2 dead eagle owls that were infected with the H5N1 bird flu in the west central part of the country on December 10. The Farm Ministry reports that since the disease has not been found in any domestic poultry, the country is still considered free from infection and exports will not be affected. The bird carcasses were found near Seosan in the northern part of the country. No human cases have been reported in the country so far.
content_2: . Specialists report that the number of deaths from avian flu in Indonesia is the highest worldwide and may be due to a slow response rate and surveillance challenges. Indonesia has the highest fatality rate from bird flu, 83%, whereas Egpyt, which has the most number of reported human cases this year, has only a 32% mortality rate. There have been 171 cases of bird flu in humans since 2003. Since it was first detected in central Java in 2003, the disease has spread to 31 out of 33 provinces nationwide, caused more than $500 million in economic losses and disrupted the livelihoods of more than 10 million people who rely on poultry, according to the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO). Many people in Indonesia do not seek medical attention in time and rely on traditional medicine. Intensive medical attention is required within the first 24-48 hours of reported symptoms to treat H5N1. Indonesia is comprised of 17,000 islands and has a population of 250 million people, making virus surveillance difficult. "It could be that milder cases simply aren't being detected due to the size and decentralization of the country, so only the really serious cases are being noticed," said Brenda Langdon, pandemic influenza adviser in the office of the UN Resident Coordinator in Jakarta.(more...
